title: Terminally ill man’s benefits stopped after he used pension to pay off debts
text:
Matthew Smith, 55, withdrew his pension to pay off debts (Picture: Gloucestershire Live /SWNS.COM)

A terminally ill man had his Universal Credit stopped after cashing in his pension to pay off his debts.

Matthew Smith, 55, was diagnosed with terminal lung cancer in March this year and can only breathe with the aid of oxygen tanks.

He decided to draw out his pension four months ago as a means of making sure he died without leaving any debts behind.

The Department of Work and Pensions (DWP) then stopped his benefits, stating that they would resume once he’d supplied evidence his pension had gone on the money he owed.

Mr Smith, from Dursley, Gloucestershire, submitted the claim but said he was forced to stockpile food as he waited for a response.

He continued: ‘I drew my pension to clear my debts. Since I did that my Universal Credit has been stopped. This is my fourth month without any Universal Credit coming in.

‘I have paid my rent and I stocked up well with food but now the money is running out. I do not understand what the hold up is.

He was left without benefits for four months (Picture: Gloucestershire Live /SWNS.COM)

‘Surely there should be something in place where those that have terminal illness have applications fast tracked.’

Mr Smith, who previously worked as a mechanic and on the docks, added that he had attempted to call the DWP, but was kept on hold for 45 minutes.

He continued: ‘To be honest I am stressed to the max. I am running out of money. It is not fair. Nobody seems to know what they are doing.

Mum has bleach thrown at her by racists making monkey noises

‘The money that I spent out was meant to be for the funeral. I hoped whatever was left in the bank the family could use to bury me.’

He added: ‘I feel my body drifting away from me. I am not in a hurry to go but I feel myself slowing. I want to get this claim sorted so I know where I stand.’

A spokesperson for the DWP confirmed they have now approved Mr Smith’s UC payments and said he is not expected to look for work.

They added: ‘We apologise for any distress caused during this difficult time and we continue to work with him to ensure he is getting all the support he’s entitled to.’

description: Universal Credit recipient Matthew Smith had his benefits stopped despite being diagnosed with terminal lung cancer in March.
